subject: MRCO
name: Beg. Mod. Standard Arabic I
info: Grammatical structures and sound patterns of Arabic. Script, pronunciation, and listening comprehension.

subject: MRCO
name: Beg. Mod. Standard Arabic II
info: Vocabulary, listening, reading, writing, speaking. Focuses on reading comprehension and grammatical structures.

subject: MRCO
name: Beg. Col. Moroccan Arabic II
info: Complex grammatical structures. Vocabulary in colloquial Moroccan Arabic.

subject: MRCO
name: Inten Low Int Mod Stand Arabic
fullname: Intensive Low Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic

subject: MRCO
name: Int. Mod. Standard Arabic I
info: Vocabulary for reading newspapers, journals, and sources such as Al-Kitaab Al-Assasi. Controlled writing assignments. Focuses on listening comprehension and reading.

subject: MRCO
name: Int. Mod. Standard Arabic II
info: Preparation for independent study in MSA. Stylistic devices, vocabulary, communicative skills. Texts from various sources.

subject: MRCO
name: Intro. to the Arabic Newspaper
info: Basic newspaper vocabulary/structure. Analysis of headlines.

subject: MRCO
name: Media Arabic
info: Media vocabulary sufficient to grasp gist of newspaper article/broadcast. Graded newspaper readings from Middle Eastern dailies. Taped material from Moroccan television/radio.

subject: MRCO
name: Gend, Mod & Soc Chg in Morocco
fullname: Gender, Modernization, and Social Change in Morocco
info: Interrelationships between gender, modernization, and social change in post-colonial Morocco. Emphasizes social institutions, religion, development, traditions, and contemporary issues.

subject: MRCO
name: Trajectories of Representation
fullname: Trajectories of Representation: Indigenous and Western Images of Morocco
info: Contemporary Moroccan literature. Selected texts, their social/political contexts. Issues that have shaped national literature and postcoloniality since 1950s.

subject: MRCO
name: Moroccan Society and Culture
info: Political, economic, societal, and cultural trends in old/modern Moroccan society. Walking tour, discussions, guest lecturers.

subject: MRCO
name: Morocco: Changes & Identities
info: The course examines the major social, cultural, political, intellectual, and human rights transformations in Morocco over the last four decades, stressing the undergoing tensions between the secular liberals and conservatives (especially Islamists) across gender, religion, language, and sexual politics. It also explores changing identities and the complexity of Moroccan cultural politics. It is based on a balanced combination of the exploration of major academic scholarship from a comparativist and multi-disciplinary perspective, and insight into the lives and experiences of Moroccans, with particular focus on the inhabitants of Fez and the region.  Above all, it traces the blended trajectories and trends in Moroccan society and culture, stressing the pressuring challenges to Moroccan national identities posed by globalization, secularism, conservatism, and fundamentalism.

subject: MRCO
name: Inten High Int Mod Stan Arabic
fullname: Intensive High Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic

subject: MRCO
name: Inten Low Adv Mod Stand Arabic
fullname: Intensive Low Advanced Modern Standard Arabic

subject: MRCO
name: Directed Research
info: This directed research provides students with the opportunity to investigate a cultural or societal topic related to Moroccan society, history, or culture under the supervision of a designated program faculty member. Students design the topic, readings, and methodology at the start of the semester with the faculty member and meet weekly with the faculty member to discuss topic development, additional readings (as needed), additional resources and considerations, and course paper progress.Semester-only students enrolled in the 3-credit research option will have a classroom component (Morocco in Context) as well as individualized instruction; academic year students will have all contact hours through individual faculty meetings. Semester and academic year students enrolled in the course for 3 credits will receive the same amount of individualized contact hours and put forth a total of 100 hours of research effort over the course of the semester.  In rare circumstances, a semester student may enroll in a 1-credit research project if they completed the summer program and are continuing into the semester.  They have the option to join the semester group for the Morocco in Context discussions and will be graded only on their research project.
